the qustion: An A1C value ≥ 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus.
explanation: Diagnostic criteria include A1C ≥ 6.5%. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: A random plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL with classic symptoms is sufficient to diagnose diabetes.
explanation: Random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL plus classic symptoms is diagnostic. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Fasting for the FPG test is defined as no caloric intake for at least 6 hours.
explanation: Fasting is at least 8 hours without caloric intake, not 6. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: In the absence of symptomatic hyperglycemia, a positive diabetes test should be confirmed by repeating the same test on another day.
explanation: Confirmation on a subsequent day is recommended if asymptomatic. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Prediabetes includes A1C values from 5.7% to 6.4%.
explanation: A1C 5.7–6.4% is listed under prediabetes. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Impaired fasting glucose (IFG) is defined by FPG 110–125 mg/dL.
explanation: IFG range given is 100–125 mg/dL. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) corresponds to a 2-hour OGTT value of 140–199 mg/dL with a 75-g load.
explanation: 2-h OGTT 140–199 mg/dL defines IGT. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: For people with prediabetes, the recommended initial weight-loss target is 7–10% of body weight.
explanation: Action for prediabetes: weight loss 7–10%. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: For prediabetes, at least 150 minutes per week of physical activity is recommended.
explanation: ≥150 min/week is specified. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Metformin therapy should be considered for prediabetes particularly when BMI > 35 kg/m², age < 60 years, or in women with prior GDM.
explanation: These are the listed situations to consider metformin. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Annual monitoring for progression to diabetes is recommended for people with prediabetes.
explanation: At least annual monitoring is advised. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: In prediabetes, screening and treatment of modifiable cardiovascular risk factors should be done annually.
explanation: Annual CVD risk factor screening/treatment is recommended. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: The general A1C goal for most adults with diabetes is around or below 7%.
explanation: Lowering A1C to below or around 7% is advised. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: A more stringent A1C target such as <6.5% may be suitable for patients with short diabetes duration, long life expectancy, and no significant CVD.
explanation: Those features support a lower A1C goal. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: A higher A1C target such as about 8% may be appropriate in patients with history of severe hypoglycemia or limited life expectancy.
explanation: Higher targets may be appropriate in such scenarios. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: HbA1c should be measured four times per year once glycemic control is achieved.
explanation: Four times/year until control is reached, then twice/year. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: For most patients, the pre-meal glucose target is 80–130 mg/dL.
explanation: Premeal target 80–130 mg/dL. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: The recommended 2-hour postprandial glucose target is < 180 mg/dL.
explanation: Postprandial <180 mg/dL at 120 minutes. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Most patients are symptomatic at the time of diabetes diagnosis.
explanation: The majority are asymptomatic. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Unintentional weight loss is a typical feature of type 1 diabetes at presentation.
explanation: Weight loss is mentioned with type 1. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Tingling or numbness in the hands/feet is more often noted in type 2 diabetes.
explanation: Neuropathic symptoms are listed with type 2. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Gestational diabetes is diabetes diagnosed in the first trimester of pregnancy.
explanation: GDM is defined as diabetes diagnosed in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is an example of monogenic diabetes listed under specific types.
explanation: Monogenic diabetes (e.g., MODY) is a specific type. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Diseases of the exocrine pancreas, such as cystic fibrosis, are included among specific types of diabetes.
explanation: Exocrine pancreas diseases are listed. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Glucocorticoid use is associated with drug-induced diabetes.
explanation: Drug- or chemical-induced diabetes includes glucocorticoids. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Smoking cessation is part of cardiovascular risk reduction in diabetes care.
explanation: Smoking cessation is included under CV risk reduction. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Aspirin therapy is not included in cardiovascular risk reduction measures for diabetes.
explanation: Aspirin therapy is part of CV risk reduction. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Complications assessment in diabetes includes kidney disease, retinopathy, neuropathy, and foot care.
explanation: These areas are explicitly assessed. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: For 2-hour postprandial monitoring, the timing is 60 minutes after the meal.
explanation: Target refers to 120 minutes after a meal. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Dietary strategies for prediabetes emphasize reduced calories and reduced dietary fat.
explanation: Reduced calories and dietary fat are recommended. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which of the following A1C values meets the diagnostic threshold for diabetes?
explanation: A1C ≥ 6.5% is diagnostic. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: A fasting plasma glucose (FPG) consistent with diabetes is:
explanation: FPG ≥126 mg/dL with at least 8 hours fasting. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Which 2-hour OGTT value (75-g load) is diagnostic for diabetes?
explanation: 2-h OGTT ≥200 mg/dL is diagnostic. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: A patient with classic symptoms has a random plasma glucose of 210 mg/dL. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: Random ≥200 mg/dL with symptoms is diagnostic of diabetes. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Which best describes the next step for an asymptomatic patient with A1C 6.6%?
a: Diagnose diabetes immediately without repeat testing
b: Repeat the same test on a subsequent day for confirmation
c: Perform only a random glucose test
explanation: Confirm on another day by repeating the same test if asymptomatic. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Which fasting glucose range defines impaired fasting glucose (IFG)?
explanation: IFG is FPG 100–125 mg/dL. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) is defined by a 2-hour OGTT of:
explanation: IGT: 2-h OGTT 140–199 mg/dL. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which A1C range is classified as prediabetes?
explanation: A1C 5.7–6.4% indicates prediabetes. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which is NOT an action recommended for prediabetes?
b: At least 150 minutes/week of physical activity
c: Increased dietary fat to raise HDL
d: Reduced calories and reduced dietary fat
explanation: Dietary advice is reduced calories and reduced fat, not increasing fat. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: In which situation is metformin especially considered for prediabetes?
explanation: Consider metformin when BMI >35 (also age <60 or prior GDM). (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: The general A1C goal for most non-pregnant adults with diabetes is:
explanation: Lowering A1C to below/around 7% is advised. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: A more stringent A1C goal (e.g., <6.5%) is most appropriate for which patient?
b: Short diabetes duration, long life expectancy, no significant CVD
explanation: These are the conditions supporting <6.5%. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: A higher A1C goal (around 8%) may be reasonable for a patient with:
a: No comorbidities and newly diagnosed diabetes
c: No prior hypoglycemia and young age
d: No complications and long life expectancy
explanation: History of severe hypoglycemia warrants looser A1C goals. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: How often should HbA1c be checked before glycemic control is achieved?
explanation: Four times/year until control is reached; then twice/year. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: The recommended pre-meal glucose target for most patients is:
explanation: Premeal 80–130 mg/dL. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: The recommended 2-hour postprandial glucose target is:
explanation: Postprandial <180 mg/dL at 120 minutes. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which of the following is a common symptom listed for diabetes?
explanation: Polyuria is a classic symptom. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which presentation is more often associated with type 1 diabetes?
explanation: Weight loss is mentioned with type 1. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which of the following patients most closely matches the slide’s definition of GDM?
b: Diabetes diagnosed in the second or third trimester
explanation: GDM is diabetes diagnosed in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which is listed under specific types of diabetes?
explanation: Monogenic diabetes is included under specific types. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which condition is cited as an exocrine pancreatic disease associated with diabetes?
explanation: Cystic fibrosis is listed under exocrine pancreas disease. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which medication class is named as a cause of drug-induced diabetes?
explanation: Glucocorticoid use is cited. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which of the following is NOT part of the cardiovascular risk reduction list?
explanation: Smoking cessation, HTN and lipid management, aspirin, and exercise are listed. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which exercise target aligns with the recommendations mentioned?
explanation: ≥150 min/week is recommended. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which complication is specifically listed for assessment in diabetes care?
explanation: Kidney disease is named among complications to assess. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which of the following clusters represents microvascular complications highlighted in the slides?
explanation: Retinopathy, kidney disease, neuropathy are listed. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which statement about symptoms is MOST accurate per the slides?
c: Most present with severe weight gain
explanation: Majority asymptomatic is explicitly stated. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which of the following is a classic hyperglycemia symptom mentioned?
explanation: Thirst is included among classic symptoms. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which sign suggests chronic hyperglycemia per the slide list?
explanation: Slow healing is listed as a symptom/sign. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which of the following BEST fits the prediabetes action plan?
a: No lifestyle changes; metformin for all
d: Increase dietary fat to maintain weight
explanation: Lifestyle targets are weight loss 7–10% and ≥150 min/week activity. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which of the following is TRUE regarding confirmation of diagnosis?
a: Confirm by repeating any different test
b: Confirm by repeating the same test on a later day if no symptoms
explanation: Repeat the same test if asymptomatic. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Which combination is correct for glucose targets?
explanation: Targets are 80–130 (premeal) and <180 at 2 hours. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which of these lifestyle components is explicitly listed under cardiovascular risk reduction?
explanation: Smoking cessation is cited. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: For a patient with long-standing diabetes and extensive comorbidities, an appropriate A1C goal may be:
explanation: Higher goals (~8%) may be appropriate in such scenarios. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which is TRUE regarding postprandial glucose assessment in the slides?
a: Measured 30 minutes after a meal; target <140 mg/dL
b: Measured 60 minutes after a meal; target <160 mg/dL
c: Measured 120 minutes after a meal; target <180 mg/dL
explanation: 2-hour timing with target <180 mg/dL. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which of the following is a recommended dietary strategy in prediabetes?
explanation: Reduced calories and fat are recommended. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which is an example of a neuropathic symptom highlighted on the slides?
explanation: Tingling, pain or numbness in hands/feet (type 2). (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which of these is a classic hyperglycemia symptom per the list?
explanation: Feeling very hungry is listed among common symptoms. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which screening/monitoring frequency is recommended for prediabetes progression?
explanation: At least annual monitoring is recommended. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which of the following sets contains ONLY diabetes types listed on the slide?
explanation: Types listed include T1DM, T2DM, GDM, and specific types such as monogenic. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which is TRUE regarding fasting requirements for FPG testing?
a: At least 8 hours without caloric intake
explanation: Fasting is no caloric intake for ≥8 hours. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Which combination best reflects the slides’ lifestyle targets for prediabetes?
c: Weight gain to build muscle; vigorous only
explanation: 7–10% weight loss and ≥150 min/week activity. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which is NOT listed as a domain to assess for complications?
explanation: Retina, kidney, neuropathy, and foot care are listed; COPD is not. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which of the following is TRUE about the symptomatic profile at presentation?
explanation: Slides note majority asymptomatic; classic symptoms listed. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which statement about confirmation of diagnosis is FALSE?
a: If asymptomatic, repeat the same test another day
b: If symptomatic with random ≥200 mg/dL, diagnosis can be made
c: If asymptomatic, no confirmation is necessary
d: Repetition is for the same test, not necessarily a different one
explanation: Asymptomatic positive requires confirmation by repeating the same test. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Which target pair is most consistent with the slides?
explanation: 80–130 and <180 at 2 h are given targets. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which of the following is included in cardiovascular risk reduction per the slide?
explanation: Aspirin and exercise (≥150 min/week) are listed. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which of the following is a classic symptom listed for diabetes?
explanation: Extreme fatigue is included among common symptoms. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which is the BEST description of the OGTT protocol referenced?
explanation: A 75-g load with 2-h value is specified. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: Which patient scenario warrants considering metformin for prediabetes per the slides?
explanation: BMI >35 and prior GDM (also age <60) are listed. (Slide p. 10)
